Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I was looking forward to the family gathering all week. My daughter had called, reminding me to bring my famous apple pie, and my grandson was excited to show me his new bike. As a grandparent, I felt the pull to be present, to laugh and share stories, to be the steady presence my family counted on. That morning, I was at the station, running through my routine check of the ambulance’s first-aid kit. Every bandage, every vial, every tool had to be accounted for—lives depended on it. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Family gathering at 2 PM.” I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of both uniforms I wore. My supervisor expected me to be thorough, to never cut corners, because a missing supply could mean the difference between life and death. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the warmth of my family and the cold, clinical responsibility of my job. I stood there, first-aid kit open, hands trembling, torn between the call of home and the call of duty, unsure which role I could bear to let down.
